Crypto fail: assets in Nintendo games for the NVidia Shield TV are encrypted with per-asset keys derived from name + size. However, the last step combines a derived key with a hardcoded base key....using and instead of xor.

This means all asset keys are mostly zero bits, lol....

1. Be humble: Code written by experts with decades of experience has security bugs, so yours does too. Where are they?
2. Be pedantic: Understand precisely how functions/libraries behave, don’t rely on it unless it’s documented.
3. Never start a new project in C/C++.

1092293904089571329.text: I've been working on an implementation of the Sonic MPC for BLS12-381, to give succinct zero-knowledge to everyone with minimal trust. There are some new techniques and ideas that I want to explore with a wider community before we begin. DM me if you're interested in helping!

1091122019469451265.text: Our scheme achieves marginal verification costs that are similar (and probably concretely better) than Groth16. In some settings, like with many proofs for the same circuit, we can even have smaller (marginal) proof sizes than Groth16!

1091121741269688323.text: In any case, we only ever need to perform a fixed constant number of pairing operations for an entire batch of proofs, regardless of what techniques are applied, as our proofs never contain elements of G2.

1091121600710160386.text: Finally, we can achieve full succinctness (either for an individual proof, or a batch of proofs) using some extra techniques that add some overhead, but not necessarily much for the prover.

1091121450675650562.text: We can instead also amortize away the evaluation so that, in batch verification, the marginal cost of verifying a proof is constant, even if the proofs cannot be individually verified succinctly.

1091121198711287808.text: In the simplest setting our proofs have 4 G1 elements and 2 Fp elements, but require a linear-time polynomial evaluation in the field. (This is concretely more efficient than the linear-size group exponentiation required by Bulletproofs, even when applying batching.)

1091120692060254208.text: We improve on a previous scheme by Groth et al. (https://ia.cr/2018/280 ) in that our SRS is only linear in the size of the supported circuits, and so our construction is practical common circuit sizes.

1091120453500821504.text: Sonic doesn't require a trusted setup for each circuit, but only a single setup for all circuits. The setup never has to end, so it can be secured indefinitely by accumulating more contributions. (Only one previous contributor must be honest.)

1091120278736760832.text: I'm happy to announce Sonic, a new zero-knowledge SNARK developed in collaboration with Mary Maller, Markulf Kohlweiss and Sarah Meiklejohn. https://ia.cr/2019/099

1087571257057406976.text:
Here's an "embedded" curve over ristretto255's scalar field

-x^2 + y^2 = 1 - (86649/86650)x^2y^2

which is Ristretto-ready and birationally equivalent to

y^2 = x^3 + 346598x^2 + x (and it's twist secure)

Any other suggestions?

1077392959245434880.text: (and everyone else in the audience is working on their presentation while you're talking, lol...)

1077390107441737734.text: The actual conference presentations are hilarious. There are usually two or three people in the audience who understand the paper, and they would have read it if you posted it on eprint anyway.

1077389750065979392.text: We need to think of the crypto field like we think of medicine and similar fields. If we stall making progress, more people get hurt and oppressed. Privacy and security are extremely important. Years are being wasted right now.

1077389423547887616.text: I'm not an academic so I just don't see the point of this crap. I'm working on a paper with compelling improvements in the field, and we have to spend so much time dressing it up for the conference that we deprive the public of the paper for months.

1077389154261000192.text: Why not just post your paper on eprint? The reviewers at crypto conferences will not find actual flaws (they don't have time), you will compromise your paper with marketing bullshit (to get into the conference), and GG if the expert reviewers are conflicts of interest.
